CatDescriptText: Mattie Boyd, housewife, 5 Mercer Street and Norman Stewart, foreman, North Side, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, December 24, 1960, pg. A1 with question "Do you think that President-elect Kennedy was sincere in offering Congressman William Dawson, of Chicago, the cabinet position of Postmaster-General?"  Mrs. Boyd's answer reads: "I think that it was just a 'front' to make us think that he is thinking of us, when, really, he does not."  Mr. Stewart's answer reads: "Yes I believe he was sincere, and I think Dawson was sincere, also, and did a good thing when he turned down good thing when he turned down the offer with the words: ' I think I can do more for my people as a Congressman from Illinois rather than in a cabinet spot.'  If he had accepted the Postmaster General position, the only jurisdiction he would have had would have had would have been in the post office."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Mattie Boyd wearing dark coat and head scarf, standing on sidewalk in front of RAAB Clothes sign, Wood Street, Downtown; Portrait of Norman Stewart wearing moustache and jacket with toggles, standing on sidewalk in front of RAAB Clothes sign, Wood Street, Downtown
